name: Probability Axiom 1: Non-negativity
statement: The probability of any event A is greater than or equal to 0.
philosophy: Probabilities represent real-world likelihoods and must be non-negative.

name: Probability Axiom 2: Normalization
statement: The probability of the sample space is 1.
philosophy: The certainty that some outcome will occur is complete.

name: Probability Axiom 3: Additivity
statement: If A and B are mutually exclusive events, then P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B).
formal: A ∩ B = ∅ → P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B)
philosophy: For disjoint events, total probability is additive.

name: Complement Rule
philosophy: The likelihood of not happening complements happening.

name: Conditional Probability
statement: P(A | B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B), provided P(B) > 0.
philosophy: Conditioning filters the sample space to within event B.

name: Independence Definition
statement: Events A and B are independent if P(A ∩ B) = P(A) · P(B).
philosophy: Independence implies no informational gain between events.

name: Expected Value (Finite)
statement: The expected value of a discrete variable is the weighted sum of outcomes.
philosophy: Expectation reflects the long-run average outcome.

name: Linearity of Expectation
statement: E[X + Y] = E[X] + E[Y] regardless of dependence.
philosophy: A powerful property that bypasses dependence.
